headline.main: Still Spooked by High-Fructose Corn Syrup

docs.abstract: Corn refiners say their sweetners are just fine in moderation, but to many people, high fructose corn syrup raises concerns.
docs.lead_paragraph: By now most everyone has seen ads from the Corn Refiners Association, claiming that our fears about high-fructose corn syrup are misplaced. Since our kids will soon be loading up on Halloween treats laden with the substance, it's a good time to consider why so many people find corn sweeteners so scary.
docs.snippet: Corn refiners say their sweetners are just fine in moderation, but to many people, high fructose corn syrup raises concerns.

docs.abstract: A team of researchers has found that the data collected by industry-sponsored studies is better than that collected in other studies.
docs.lead_paragraph: In 2005, The Journal of the American Medical Association cited "concerns about misleading reporting of industry-sponsored research" to justify its stricter standards for any such research to be considered for publication. The new policy, requiring researchers with no financial connections to the sponsor to vouch for the data and perform statistical work, was promptly criticized in an editorial in The British Medical Journal as "manifestly unfair" because it created a "a hierarchy of purity among authors."
docs.snippet: A team of researchers has found that the data collected by industry-sponsored studies is better than that collected in other studies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Complex diet regimens are starting to look like exotic mortgages and, just like a reliable savings account, good old calorie counting is coming back into fashion.
docs.snippet: Complex diet regimens are starting to look like exotic mortgages and, just like a reliable savings account, good old calorie counting is coming back into fashion.

headline.print_headline: Is Health Care a Game of Statistics?
